Ridgewood, Queens, NY 5/4/2012 2 Check-ins Here I hadn't been here before but since I was heading to an event at City Bar&didn't want to spend a ton of money on dinner, I decided to stop in here after recently learning that they don't just sell soup. They also have "create your own" salads&I found that my meal with water was cheaper than at the specialty salad places.
Another plus is they have honey mustard dressing. Seems to be more value for your buck here. The location itself is a little small but there was sufficient seating when I came in.
I've not had the soup but with so many different varieties, maybe I'll be motivated to try one sometime. I also liked getting the free oyster crackers with my order. Queens, NY 6/4/2012 3 Check-ins Here All Hale the soup genius behind this chain! Hale&Hearty is my go-to lunch spot, especially during the cold winter months. I'm a huge soup person. My favorites are the jambalaya, clam chowders, chicken pot pie, and tons of others. I love that the soups change daily and they have a new sandwich every month. It keeps things changing so I can always try new things. They also carry salad if you're into leafy greens. I've only had one thing I wasn't a fan of here in the many many many times I take out. Its hard to go wrong when they have so many choices and they let you try the soup before you buy.
This location tends to be hellish during lunch because of the swarms of people in the tiny narrow storefront. They have a tiny amount of seating in the back and the cashiers move quickly, but try not to be offended if you get shoved around a bit. They also only keep hours consistent with the 9-5pm crowd, so they're not a good dinner option.

Union, NJ 3/12/2012 (2.50 stars) There are some great soup lunches to be had in Manhattan. Few choices are more warming, comforting or flat-out delicious than a great bowl of soup. IMRHO, the Soup Spot and Soup Cart (a few blocks north) at bargain prices, and famous Soup Man make much better soup and offer better service. Hale and Hearty offer two things which the others don't.
First, the variety here is amazing. There are soup varieties offer here which expand the international food parameters and challenge contemporary culinary bounds. Although a few taste remarkably similar, those which I've tasted have been good.
Next, and this should not be minimized, Hale and Hearty offers tables and chairs.
You'll find a pricing system of flavors and sizes which requires 20/20 vision to read. Their prices are in the higher range for what is offered, but still reasonable when viewed among lunchtime options in Midtown. Soups are also available with half- or full-sized sandwiches, and I'm not a huge fan of their sandwiches. Soup-and-salad combos are also sold.

Brookline, MA 2/5/2012 I am excited to find such a healthy change! I had no idea it existed until I walked by on my most recent trip to NY.
I got the Winter Dumpling Soup, and it was fantastic. It is so difficult to find soups that are really filling without having a cream base. I love soups with a squash base! It taste delicious, and doesn't sit in your stomach the way that a cream-based soup does. Yum!
I also got a sandwich with mozzarella, tomato, avocado and a little lemon zest, a combination I wouldn't have really thought of myself, but was surprisingly delicious!
The whole ordering process was a little bit rushed, but what can you expect in a fast food restaurant at lunch time on a week day? The healthy options and clean running lines more than made up for any confusion that was caused by the hustle and bustle of the city life. Just to name a couple delicious healthy bites: baked veggie chips, Gus' Grown Up Soda (less sugar, all natural!)
Definitely recommend stopping in for a quick bite while exploring the city!

Astoria, Queens, NY 6/4/2011 1 Check-in Here As far as this particular chain goes, you can't go terribly wrong. I stopped in here around 5:30/6:00 pm for a quick bite before doing a practice LSAT test at the library across the street, and it served my purposes nicely.
Being that I was right next to Bryant Park and the NYPL (e.g. tourist central), I was looking for something relatively inexpensive and fast. This Hale&Hearty location gave me the fast part, but it was a tad expensive for what I got.
Went with a chicken caesar salad sandwich (half) and picked up one of their pre-packaged brownies, and it came out to a little under $7. The half sandwich was somewhere around $4 or $5 so that was an expensive little dessert! A whole sandwich starts out around $7ish, and I'll definitely say that in general they're a little skimpy with the fillings. It's a good thing my body thrives on carbs with the mostly bread sandwich I was consuming. Why is it that I can never find a healthy looking sandwich (tip: "healthy" in this context means loaded with meat, cheese, etc.) at any place but a dingy looking deli on the corner? And why are those delis far cheaper than these chains?
Mini-diatribe on sandwich/price inequities aside, I got what I needed at the time, but it's more expensive than it should be and they skimp a little bit on their sandwiches.

New York, NY 1/31/2009 I frequently stop into Hale&Hearty to pick up a "quick lunch". "Quick" being the operative word.
Due to slim pickings of general and reasonably priced restaurants in the Bryant Park area compared to Times Square, Grand Central or Rockefeller Center, the establishments around Bryant Park are subject to the subject to be busy at peak times and dead the rest of the day. This H&H location is swarming like a hive of bees at lunchtime. So go early or don't go. This location is very small and there are about 10 or 15 seats. Its so small that when you're ordering soup your directly on top of the two tables closest to the register. This is completely inappropriate. If you looking for a place to unwind during lunch, this H&H is not the place. During nice weather, you're better off going across the street to Bryant Park.
The lines...oh man. The lines can be so long that they intertwine and you often have to ask the person in front of you, "which line are you in? Soup or Salad?" On many occasions, the salad line snakes out the door or blocks it.
The staff is friendly but can appear short as they are trying their best to quickly service people and get them out the door.
Soups are a bit expensive but worth it in my book. There are about 30 soups on their menu. Every day the soup selection changes. Visit the H&H website and vote for you favorite soup(s) as well as set yourself up to receive and email notifications when (one of) your favorite soup(s) is on the menu. My suggestion is that you try your soup selection before buying, even if its one of your favorites or something you've bought before.
Their salads are standard with the usual suspects as toppings unfortunately their salad dressings are Gawd awful! I've tried three or four dressings and each time they've ruined my perfectly built salad!
I've never tried the sandwiches or pre-made salads, as the sandwiches look skimpy and over priced and pre made salads look unappealing.
Listed below are my favorite soups. Give them a try.
Chicken&Sausage Jambalaya Chicken and Corn Bisque Chicken Marsala with Wild Mushrooms Chicken Pot Pie Chicken, Mushroom and Wild Rice Curried Shrimp and Roasted Corn Bisque
Make sure to get your bean or green card stamped with each purchase. 10 stamps entitle you to a free soup or salad.
This location does have delivery, I've never used the service but others I know have and say its slow and to avoid using it.

But its soup- soup in and of itself is not a very expensive product, so paying fairly steep, sandiwch like prices for soup here- a takeout place that's not a gourmet restaurant kills the flavor somewhat.
That being said, focusing on the product, they have an excellent Chicken Marsala soup, very good chilis, and the ethnic soups like the Moroccan Chicken are also quite good. They let you try a sip of the soup before eating, so if something sounds intriguing by all means try it.

New York, NY 12/1/2008 Albert Einstein once said "The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results". Think about this quote for a second and ask yourself, does this sound like your lunch routine?
Well if you answered, YES, then you probably work in midtown.
I despise the options I have around me during my little pocket of freedom I call lunchbreak. I eat the same bland turkey sandwiches, from the same deli with a different name and location. A smorgasbord of sandwiches, salad bars, burritos, pastas, buffets, sushi, and Mongolian grills. While the list might seem diverse, trust me, it isn't.
Enter Hale&Hearty. Does this place break the mold I so desperately seek to escape during my lunch hour?...well... yes, but being the fastest rabbit in a land full of turkeys is nothing to be proud of ( that's assuming turkeys are slow, im not entirely sure?). It doesn't quench my thirst for a decent lunch, but it does however make things bearable.
With that said, I hold a special place in my heart for Hale&Hearty. It's Curried Chicken Chowder Soup breaks up the monotony of my lunches and adds a splash of color to my continuous grays. Even if that color is dull and muted, its something until I make it home for a proper meal.
God bless you Curried Chicken Chowder, god bless you.

NY 11/14/2008 Let me preface this by offering one little tidbit of advice: don't expect to get a good back massage from a one armed retarded hooker.
That is by long way of saying that you can't expect a restaurant to be very good at something it doesn't necessarily do. Hale and Hearty makes pretty good soup--three, maybe four star soup--but it doesn't make a good chili.
It doesn't make a good chili because (wait for it) chili is not soup. Its consistency is different, its flavors richer, more surprising. Sure, they are both liquid-based slow cooked stew-like meals, but chili is an art. It is a special middle child that need lots of understand to come into its own.
The chili at Hale and Hearty looked like diahrria. It didn't taste much better either. But I judge them a little too harshly.
After all, even a one-armed hooker has her talents.
Hale and Hearty makes a great corn chowder soup and that is no small thing. The good folk behind the counter, while prone to acting as if you aren't standing there waiting to order lunch, dish out some surprising soups. Sadly the sandwiches are about as lackluster as the chili. I would recommend that you go across the park after picking up your soup a H&H to Pax for a sandwich.
